data: Developing Cryogenic Energy Storage at Refrigerated Warehouses as an Interactive Hub to Integrate Renewable Energy in Industrial Food Refrigeration and to Enhance PowerGrid Sustainability

The CryoHub innovation project will investigate and extend the potential of large-scale Cryogenic Energy Storage (CES) and will apply the stored energy for both cooling and energy generation. By employing Renewable Energy Sources (RES) to liquefy and store cryogens, CryoHub will balance the power grid, while meeting the cooling demand of a refrigerated food warehouse and recovering the waste heat from its equipment and components.
The intermittent supply is a major obstacle to the RES power market. In reality, RES are fickle forces, prone to over-producing when demand is low and failing to meet requirements when demand peaks. Europe is about to generate 20% of its required energy from RES by 2020, so that the proper RES integration poses continent-wide challenges.
The Cryogenic Energy Storage (CES), and particularly the Liquid Air Energy Storage (LAES), is a promising technology enabling on-site storage of RES energy during periods of high generation and its use at peak grid demand. Thus, CES acts as Grid Energy Storage (GES), where cryogen is boiled to drive a turbine and to restore electricity to the grid. To date, CES applications have been rather limited by the poor round trip efficiency (ratio between energies spent for and retrieved from energy storage) due to unrecovered energy losses.
The CryoHub project is therefore designed to maximise the CES efficiency by recovering energy from cooling and heating in a perfect RES-driven cycle of cryogen liquefaction, storage, distribution and efficient use. Refrigerated warehouses for chilled and frozen food commodities are large electricity consumers, possess powerful installed capacities for cooling and heating and waste substantial amounts of heat. Such facilities provide the ideal industrial environment to advance and demonstrate the LAES benefits.
CryoHub will thus resolve most of the above-mentioned problems at one go, thereby paving the way for broader market prospects for CES-based technologies across Europe.

60 young people  from Ukraine, Germany , Portugal, Romania , Italy, Russia and Turkey will take part in the ten-day youth exchange "Frankfurt is a € pean city" in October 2014.
On  the one hand Frankfurt is a big German metropole , on the other hand Frankfurt is an example of how the multicultural society can function peacefully, productive and mutually enriching. For this reason, we meet just in this city, to talk about the present state and the future of Europe . Both advantages and the positive, as well as problems and concerns are to be disscussed: the new, shiny building of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt's harbor and the financial crisis , EU enlargement plans and the Icelandic retraction of the EU accession declaration, Frankfurt Marathon and the growing number of smoking young people. It is particularly gratifying that not only participants from the EU countries  participate in this discussion, but also young people from neighboring partner countries.
In thematically diverse workshops, role plays, discussions and roundtables  the adolescents maneuver, participation opportunities and career prospects for young people in Europe are to be explored.
In addition to the various project results such as  reports,  photogalleries and newspaper articles , we hope to create a constructive suggestion list which consists of  any possible improvements in areas of public transport , ecology and tourism in the city . This list is to be forwarded to the municipal magistrate.

Soon after the 25th anniversary of the Berlin Wall 60 young people aged 16+ from Germany, England, Ukraine, Macedonia, Italy, Romania, Russia, Spain and Slovakia will meet in Berlin to reflect the impact of this event on the development of Europe and on its subsequent integration.
The project "No Walls!" purposes to investigate the reasons (social, political, economic, ethnic, geographical, historical, etc.) leading to the (regional) separation in different countries. The key question that must be answered: Are the preconditions for splitting up often similar? If so, what can be politically and socio-economically done to prevent splitting or avoid it. Both the example of the reunified Germany, as well as of the referendum in Scotland should teach the young people to find a real possible alternative to separation, taking into account the current political/economic situation. The young people are challenged to construct the strategies to counteract the separation tendency (at regional, national and European level) and underline Union benefits.
In thematically diverse workshops, role plays, discussions and roundtables everyone can express himself so that future Europeans would not have walls any more!
EMANCIPER Mayotte par la mobilité européenne dans la formation professionnelle

In 2014, 60% of the Mayotte’s citizens are under 25 years old and 47% of the young people are unemployed. Most of them have never left this French Indian Ocean island and still live in the neighbourhood where they were born. The education level and social, intercultural skills are low. The project ‘EMANCIPER EMPOWER Mayotte by the European mobility in VET’ addresses an urgent and crucial need on the Mayotte territory: develop the employability of young people by encouraging the mobility of 22 participants who will work as a trainee in an enterprise based in London (UK) during 6 months. This mobility will allow them to enhance their professional skills by acquiring transferable skills that are relevant to their profession and other key skills (English language, social and intercultural skills). EMANCIPER targets Vocational Education Training (VET) students of DAESA training centre, the coordinating organisation. Around 4 500 VET and high Education students from Mayotte go in metropolis for studying. The school dropout of students who don’t validate a training or diploma is very high (80%). Therefore, DAESA’s team brings a very solid support to the learners all along the project (before, during and after the mobility) and organize a mobility training before the departure (logistics, language, intercultural learning). The 22 participants will be spread out in 3 groups over the duration of the project (24 months). ZI consultancy, the intermediary organization will act as the focal point at the local level during the mobility and the entry point with the host enterprises. The project impact is to develop young mobility in Mayotte and the number of EU applications. Indeed, DAESA is the only organization which has submitted an ERASMUS+ application. DAESA wishes to become an active and substantial actor in the international and European mobility for VET students. DAESA would like to create a platform giving support to project leaders for facilitating the submission of EU funding applications. Recently, Mayotte became an EU’s outermost regions. For most of the citizens, the European idea is very abstract and unclear. EMANCIPER allows them to raise their curiosity towards EU citizenship and opportunities. A mobility forum will be organized for the general public and the institutional actors, especially the County Council of Mayotte who will act as the co-founder of the project.
